content.value: Hello,Â blog!Â No,Â IÂ swearÂ thisÂ isn'tÂ aÂ placeholder.Â IÂ mean,Â itÂ wasÂ whenÂ IÂ wasÂ goingÂ throughÂ thisÂ bootcamp,Â butÂ sinceÂ IÂ alwaysÂ toldÂ myself:Â "Alyssa,Â youÂ shouldÂ codeÂ yourÂ ownÂ blog!Â Grown-assÂ adultsÂ whoÂ haveÂ programmingÂ jobsÂ andÂ personalÂ websitesÂ mustÂ haveÂ aÂ blogÂ whereÂ theyÂ talkÂ aboutÂ code!"Â

AndÂ toÂ that,Â IÂ say, phooey! TalkingÂ aboutÂ codeÂ allÂ dayÂ getsÂ boring.Â AndÂ writingÂ aÂ blogpostÂ aboutÂ howÂ IÂ actuallyÂ learnedÂ howÂ toÂ properlyÂ learnÂ (x)Â libraryÂ inÂ javascriptÂ kindaÂ scaresÂ me,Â becauseÂ IÂ knowÂ someoneÂ likeÂ theÂ programmerÂ IÂ wasÂ fiveÂ yearsÂ agoÂ wouldÂ beÂ scouringÂ throughÂ itÂ tryingÂ toÂ figureÂ outÂ whatÂ wentÂ wrongÂ withÂ
their

Â code.Â WhatÂ ifÂ IÂ giveÂ themÂ theÂ wrongÂ answer?Â OrÂ whatÂ ifÂ they'reÂ lookingÂ atÂ itÂ tenÂ yearsÂ fromÂ nowÂ andÂ whateverÂ IÂ learned,Â howeverÂ correctÂ itÂ wasÂ inÂ 2020,Â isÂ extremelyÂ badÂ practiceÂ andÂ obsoleteÂ inÂ 2030?Â IÂ tendÂ toÂ worryÂ aÂ lot,Â ifÂ youÂ didn'tÂ knowÂ already.Â IÂ guessÂ ifÂ IÂ getÂ myÂ confidenceÂ upÂ inÂ severalÂ monthsÂ I'llÂ finallyÂ getÂ aroundÂ toÂ writingÂ aÂ blogÂ postÂ alongÂ theÂ linesÂ ofÂ "10Â CoolÂ ThingsÂ IÂ LearnedÂ AboutÂ ProgrammingÂ WhileÂ GoingÂ ThroughÂ aÂ ReactÂ Bootcamp!Â You'llÂ NeverÂ BelieveÂ #7!"Â andÂ theÂ entireÂ timeÂ I'llÂ talkÂ aboutÂ howÂ IÂ neverÂ properlyÂ learnedÂ vanillaÂ JSÂ andÂ mostÂ ofÂ myÂ gripesÂ withÂ javascriptÂ areÂ unfounded/noÂ longerÂ theÂ case.Â Whoops,Â IÂ just did.

ThatÂ aside,Â IÂ haven'tÂ trulyÂ bloggedÂ sinceÂ myÂ middleÂ schoolÂ days,Â andÂ itÂ stillÂ amazesÂ meÂ thatÂ asÂ aÂ childÂ IÂ hadÂ soÂ muchÂ toÂ sayÂ aboutÂ absolutelyÂ nothing.Â (AlthoughÂ toÂ beÂ fair,Â animeÂ circlesÂ inÂ theÂ mid/lateÂ 00'sÂ hadÂ aÂ tendencyÂ toÂ getÂ prettyÂ vicious.Â ğŸ˜…)SoÂ what'sÂ changedÂ sinceÂ then?Â Well...
IÂ didn'tÂ becomeÂ aÂ doctor.

ThisÂ mayÂ beÂ oldÂ newsÂ toÂ mostÂ folks.Â SometimeÂ duringÂ myÂ juniorÂ yearÂ of High School, after studying stuff like epidemiology and medical terminology IÂ realizedÂ thatÂ medicineÂ reallyÂ wasn'tÂ forÂ me. Instead, whatÂ wasÂ forÂ meÂ wasÂ somethingÂ IÂ wasÂ doingÂ forÂ funsiesÂ allÂ along.Â IÂ knewÂ thatÂ IÂ wantedÂ toÂ doÂ somethingÂ withÂ computers,Â butÂ IÂ wasn'tÂ sureÂ what; mostÂ ofÂ whatÂ IÂ didÂ inÂ myÂ spareÂ timeÂ upÂ untilÂ thenÂ wasÂ designÂ websitesÂ andÂ makeÂ stupidÂ memesÂ inÂ photoshop.Â InitiallyÂ IÂ figuredÂ computerÂ engineeringÂ wouldÂ beÂ forÂ meÂ (sinceÂ freshman-year-of-college-meÂ assumedÂ IÂ wasÂ aÂ veryÂ smartÂ person,Â andÂ smartÂ peopleÂ doÂ engineering -- or so I thought)Â butÂ realizedÂ computer/electricalÂ engineeringÂ wasn'tÂ somethingÂ IÂ wasÂ terribleÂ interestedÂ inÂ orÂ veryÂ goodÂ at.Â IÂ switchedÂ myÂ majorÂ toÂ ComputerÂ ScienceÂ andÂ feltÂ likeÂ itÂ wasÂ aÂ muchÂ betterÂ fit.Â InitiallyÂ IÂ wasÂ lookingÂ intoÂ courseworkÂ that'dÂ nabÂ meÂ aÂ jobÂ inÂ infosec,Â butÂ fellÂ inÂ loveÂ withÂ softwareÂ developmentÂ alongÂ theÂ way.Â IÂ wentÂ toÂ myÂ firstÂ hackathon:
HackHERSÂ atÂ RutgersÂ University
Â andÂ didÂ myÂ firstÂ hackÂ withÂ myÂ goodÂ pal/sailorÂ senshi/hackathonÂ senpaiÂ
Constantina

.Â IÂ didn'tÂ quiteÂ getÂ sourceÂ control/gitÂ atÂ theÂ timeÂ orÂ theÂ factÂ thatÂ IÂ hadÂ noÂ rules,Â aÂ LeapÂ MotionÂ ControllerÂ (thatÂ weÂ endedÂ upÂ notÂ using),Â anÂ near-infiniteÂ amountÂ ofÂ caffeineÂ andÂ anÂ ass-loadÂ ofÂ techÂ swagÂ forÂ $Free.99,Â butÂ IÂ wasÂ inÂ absoluteÂ heaven.Â ItÂ stillÂ amazesÂ meÂ fiveÂ yearsÂ laterÂ thatÂ IÂ canÂ justÂ tapÂ onÂ aÂ computerÂ keyboardÂ allÂ dayÂ andÂ makeÂ thingsÂ forÂ people.
IÂ HADÂ AÂ KID!!

I'mÂ honestlyÂ tryingÂ toÂ stillÂ wrapÂ myÂ headÂ aroundÂ thisÂ one.Â TheÂ eventsÂ leadingÂ upÂ toÂ meÂ findingÂ outÂ honestlyÂ playedÂ outÂ likeÂ aÂ telenovela.Â IÂ don'tÂ wantÂ toÂ goÂ intoÂ tooÂ muchÂ detail,Â butÂ theÂ longÂ andÂ shortÂ ofÂ itÂ wasÂ thatÂ IÂ wasÂ beingÂ harassedÂ forÂ nearlyÂ aÂ wholeÂ monthÂ byÂ anÂ exÂ ofÂ mineÂ beforeÂ findingÂ outÂ thatÂ theÂ stomachÂ virusÂ IÂ thoughtÂ IÂ hadÂ wasn'tÂ exactlyÂ stomachÂ virus,Â butÂ myÂ uterusÂ gettingÂ aÂ newÂ tenant.Â MyÂ spouseÂ (then-boyfriend)Â andÂ IÂ definitelyÂ weren'tÂ readyÂ forÂ aÂ kid.Â AndÂ justÂ ourÂ luckÂ --Â IÂ endedÂ upÂ beingÂ aÂ CoronabumperÂ
(classÂ ofÂ AprilÂ 2020,Â baby!)
Â It'sÂ beenÂ anÂ interestingÂ andÂ humblingÂ experience,Â asÂ wellÂ asÂ aÂ wonderfulÂ exerciseÂ forÂ meÂ inÂ learningÂ howÂ toÂ notÂ feelÂ weirdÂ askingÂ forÂ help.Â
IÂ gotÂ hitched?!

TheÂ lastÂ timeÂ IÂ wroteÂ thisÂ blogÂ entryÂ wasÂ aroundÂ September?Â BetweenÂ thenÂ andÂ now,Â myÂ spouseÂ andÂ IÂ hadÂ aÂ bitÂ ofÂ aÂ healthÂ scareÂ --Â hisÂ sister,Â whoÂ wasÂ visitingÂ usÂ fromÂ Hungary,Â wasÂ inÂ contactÂ withÂ someoneÂ whoÂ testedÂ postiveÂ forÂ COVID-19.Â WeÂ allÂ wereÂ luckyÂ enoughÂ toÂ beÂ ableÂ toÂ getÂ tested,Â andÂ weÂ wereÂ evenÂ luckierÂ toÂ testÂ negative.Â SomehowÂ inÂ theÂ wholeÂ messÂ myÂ spouseÂ andÂ IÂ realizedÂ thatÂ we'reÂ notÂ gonnaÂ liveÂ forever,Â andÂ asÂ twoÂ peopleÂ whoÂ don'tÂ careÂ forÂ bigÂ celebrationsÂ centeredÂ aroundÂ ourselvesÂ thisÂ isÂ theÂ bestÂ wayÂ toÂ getÂ hitchedÂ withoutÂ havingÂ toÂ feelÂ badÂ forÂ notÂ handingÂ anÂ inviteÂ overÂ toÂ Mom/Dad/UncleÂ Bob.Â SinceÂ youÂ can'tÂ maskÂ aÂ baby,Â weÂ didn'tÂ bringÂ ourÂ childÂ toÂ theÂ ceremonyÂ whereÂ theyÂ couldÂ potentiallyÂ getÂ infectedÂ withÂ COVID/otherwiseÂ getÂ sick.Â
(OnÂ aÂ prettyÂ chillyÂ day,Â noÂ less!)Â

MyÂ folksÂ wereÂ onÂ vacationÂ inÂ upstateÂ NewÂ York,Â weÂ sentÂ ourÂ childÂ toÂ myÂ spouse'sÂ parentsÂ forÂ theÂ week.Â WeÂ hadÂ aÂ brief,Â outdoorÂ sociallyÂ distancedÂ ceremonyÂ withÂ threeÂ witnessesÂ
(twoÂ toÂ signÂ theÂ paperwork,Â andÂ oneÂ toÂ beÂ ourÂ photographer/hype-man/"ringÂ bearÂ ğŸ˜‰")

,Â andÂ aÂ niceÂ lunchÂ atÂ aÂ fancy-schmancyÂ steakhouse.Â AllÂ thisÂ onÂ anÂ otherwiseÂ not-so-noteworthyÂ Wednesday.Â I'dÂ haveÂ toÂ sayÂ thatÂ gettingÂ marriedÂ wasÂ prettyÂ niceÂ givenÂ theÂ circumstances,Â andÂ ifÂ itÂ keepsÂ meÂ outÂ ofÂ theÂ freyÂ ofÂ shittyÂ familialÂ politicsÂ IÂ wouldn'tÂ haveÂ itÂ otherÂ way.Â ToÂ beÂ honestÂ though,Â I'mÂ aboutÂ aÂ weekÂ andÂ aÂ halfÂ intoÂ marriedÂ life,Â andÂ notÂ muchÂ hasÂ changedÂ inÂ ourÂ dynamic.Â TheÂ onlyÂ super-coupleyÂ thingÂ ofÂ noteÂ wasÂ thatÂ weÂ gotÂ aÂ phoneÂ planÂ together.

SoÂ that'sÂ what'sÂ beenÂ goingÂ onÂ withÂ meÂ soÂ far.Â SoÂ gladÂ weÂ canÂ finallyÂ catchÂ up,Â almostÂ fifteenÂ yearsÂ later.
xoxo,Â AlyssaÂ
IÂ justÂ revampedÂ myÂ siteÂ inÂ GatsbyÂ followingÂ AndrewÂ Mead'sÂ
"TheÂ GreatÂ GatsbyÂ Bootcamp"Â onÂ Youtube
.Â AsÂ someoneÂ who'sÂ notÂ terriblyÂ familiarÂ withÂ React,Â Gatsby,Â orÂ evenÂ SCSS,Â IÂ foundÂ itÂ extremelyÂ helpful!

description.en-US: In this picture, I'm standing in front of a Major League Hacking (MLH) sign. I'm at HackHERS 2016 at Rutgers University, Cook Campus Center.I'm wearing a baggy corgi kirigurumi (a fleece character onesie), square rimmed glasses, and a pink bandana. I have several MLH stickers on the chest part of my kirigurumi. I'm giving a double thumbs up to the camera.

InÂ thisÂ pictureÂ I'mÂ withÂ myÂ spouseÂ outsideÂ theÂ countyÂ clerksÂ office.Â I'mÂ wearingÂ aÂ whiteÂ dress,Â aÂ whiteÂ clothÂ faceÂ mask,Â aÂ whiteÂ veil,Â aÂ crownÂ ofÂ artificialÂ baby'sÂ breathÂ flowers,Â aÂ blackÂ goldÂ andÂ moissaniteÂ engagement,Â ringÂ andÂ nudeÂ pumps.Â TheÂ pumpsÂ areÂ quiteÂ aÂ fewÂ shadesÂ lighterÂ thanÂ myÂ skinÂ tone.Â IÂ amÂ holdingÂ aÂ bouquetÂ ofÂ whiteÂ rosesÂ andÂ aÂ blackÂ purse.Â MyÂ spouseÂ isÂ inÂ aÂ blackÂ suit,Â aÂ blackÂ clothÂ faceÂ mask,Â aÂ whiteÂ dressÂ shirt,Â aÂ royalÂ blueÂ tie,Â aÂ whiteÂ singleÂ roseÂ boutonniereÂ withÂ babyÂ blueÂ ribbon,Â andÂ someÂ clean,Â butÂ well-wornÂ dressÂ shoes.Â HisÂ eyesÂ areÂ outÂ ofÂ frame,Â andÂ hisÂ faceÂ maskÂ obscuresÂ theÂ restÂ ofÂ hisÂ face.
In this picture I'm reading a board book titled "Blockchain for Babies" to my child, who is dressed in a white-and-blue striped onesie. His face is obscured by the book.
